abstract: A property wrapper type that can read and write a value that SwiftUI updates as the placement of focus within the scene changes.
overview:
## Overview

Use this property wrapper in conjunction with [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:equals:)] and [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:)] to describe views whose appearance and contents relate to the location of focus in the scene. When focus enters the modified view, the wrapped value of this property updates to match a given prototype value. Similarly, when focus leaves, the wrapped value of this property resets to `nil` or `false`. Setting the property’s value programmatically has the reverse effect, causing focus to move to the view associated with the updated value.

In the following example of a simple login screen, when the user presses the Sign In button and one of the fields is still empty, focus moves to that field. Otherwise, the sign-in process proceeds.

To allow for cases where focus is completely absent from a view tree, the wrapped value must be either an optional or a Boolean. Set the focus binding to `false` or `nil` as appropriate to remove focus from all bound fields. You can also use this to remove focus from a [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/TextField] and thereby dismiss the keyboard.

### Avoid ambiguous focus bindings

The same view can have multiple focus bindings. In the following example, setting `focusedField` to either `name` or `fullName` causes the field to receive focus:

On the other hand, binding the same value to two views is ambiguous. In the following example, two separate fields bind focus to the `name` value:

If the user moves focus to either field, the `focusedField` binding updates to `name`. However, if the app programmatically sets the value to `name`, SwiftUI chooses the first candidate, which in this case is the “Name” field. SwiftUI also emits a runtime warning in this case, since the repeated binding is likely a programmer error.

### Nest focusable views

It is important to consider the difference between [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:equals:)] and [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:)] with nested focusable views.

For example, consider the following code:

The code above uses [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:)], which binds focus state to the given Boolean state value. [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:)] sets `containerIsFocused` to `true` both when the `VStack` itself receives focus and *just* the `TextField` that it contains receives focus. This behavior occurs because two independent instances of `@FocusState` are used to observe the focus state of the focusable `VStack` and the `TextField`. When the `VStack` does not have focus, SwiftUI checks the view hierarchy to find the closest view with focus to set the value for `containerIsFocused`. If the `TextField` contained within this `VStack` happens to be focused, [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:)] will set `containerIsFocused` to `true`.

If there is need to observe whether only the `VStack` has focus, but not the inner TextField, consider using [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:equals:)] instead, for more granular control.

With [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:equals:)], the above code can be rewritten as follows:

With [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:equals:)], it is possible to define a custom data structure to represent focus state. In this case, a `Focus` enumeration is used. It has two cases, one for the focusable `VStack` and another for the `TextField` it contains. [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:equals:)] binds focused to `.container` only when the `VStack` itself has focus, and to `.field` when the `TextField` has focus. Because now there is only one `@FocusState` property, SwiftUI is able to disambiguate between cases when `VStack` *contains* focus and *receives* focus itself.

Note that both of the above approaches are acceptable. [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:equals:)] can be used to observe whether the given view currently receives focus. While [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/focused(_:)] can be used for the same purpose, additionally it can observe whether the given view contains focus.
